course.subject: COMP
course.name: Computer Networks
course.description: Principles, design and implementation of computer communication networks; network architecture and protocols, OSI reference model and TCP/IP networking architecture; Internet applications and requirements; transport protocols, TCP and UDP; network layer protocols, IP, routing, multicasting and broadcasting; local area networks; data link and physical layer issues; TCP congestion control, quality of service, emerging trends in networking.
course.exclusions: COMP 4622 (prior to 2018-19)

reviews.author: jiaxin27
reviews.comment_content: The content is well organized and easy to understand, but we can still learn a lot from this coruse. Really recommend this course!
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is nice and speak very confortable English. No attendance requres.
reviews.comment_grading: Good for post graduate students. Most of the student can pass the course.
reviews.comment_workload: There are 3 assignments in total. However, we are only required to  select two of them to complete. Mid and Final exams exists and we need to pass. No projects. I think the workload is very nice especially in PG course.

reviews.author: ygongae
reviews.title: An ordinary class taught by a prof hard to deal with
reviews.comment_content: The class is generally easy. Almost the same content as ug course and the material hasn't been changed for 30 years. Not useful, but understand it is not a bad thing.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturer always makes students sleepy. The things taught are pretty aged so no need be focus too much. But you still need to focus because BB will highlight some questions for homework and quizes. Some questions that may appear in quizes and finals may not appear in the slides but got mentioned in the class
reviews.comment_grading: Good. Most students get B+ (65%). Around 5/80 students get failed for this course. But it's not easy to get good grade such as A+, only 2 students get this mark. For PG students, this is not satisfactory unless you just want a B+ to pass. In addition, BB will not give B+ to those non-phd students "because they don't need"
reviews.comment_workload:
3 homeworks, each takes around 2 hours.
2 quizes and 1 final, the questions are not hard but pretty confusing. For instance, you don't know what the questions really want you to answer.

reviews.author: qian
reviews.comment_content: Covers 5 different layers of network protocols (Physical, Link, Network, Transport, Application) in top-down approach. ( Application -> Physical).
reviews.comment_teaching: (Super) Great at teaching but his speech may be too fast to follow. (Recommend to voice record his lecture)
reviews.comment_grading: 2 Assignments, Open-book Mid Term and Open-book final (Online Final examinations). I think the grading is generous and the questions for the assignments are quite easy and most of the time you will get close to 100/100 marks. The midterm/final exam questions are derived from the textbook so recommend solving some of the questions from the textbook problem sets.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is super manageable as there are max 3 assignments that are easy to finish.

reviews.author: lpwang
reviews.comment_content: This course covers basic network content according to the textbook top-to-down, mainly includes the first 6 chapter.
reviews.comment_teaching: BB is very interesting and trends to explain the details of the basic process in network. Attendance of the course is not required
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm and final exams are easy to get good grades. If you attend the course and do homework by yourself, it is not hard to get a good grade in final.
reviews.comment_workload: Two exams, about 4 assignments, including several online labs, no coding projects. The homework and exam are mainly from the exercise in the textbook.

reviews.author: Zcc
reviews.comment_content: The content is good for layman.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. BB is teaching in a good way that is easy to unsderstand
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is ok though I study hard. But professor is very fair to everyone. In that semester, our TA also join the class as a student. He can access some material on canvas that we can not. To be fair to everyone, professor released the hidden material for us including the final exam in the last year which is very useful material for us to prepare the exam.

reviews.author: STIWEIR
reviews.comment_content: The course content is similar to the corresponding UG course, so you may find it almost impossible to learn something advanced. However, the course does cover the basics of top-down hierarchical network architecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's elaboration is clear and easy to understand, but some may say it is bland.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is okay, and it is not hard to get a B+ as long as you finish all the assignments and get some points in exams.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is reasonable, including four assignments(each costs less than two hours to finish), one mid-term exam, and one final exam.

reviews.author: Andong
reviews.comment_content: The course's content includes basics of computer networking - in a top-down approach. I believe the course successfully covers basics that a CS student should know as common sense. Though, the contents are basically at a "undergrad course", it would be better if more advances topics of networking can be covered.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. BB's teaching is informative and the delivery is interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: Hmm as a new comer to ust, I do not very sure how students are finally graded. I ranked top 10% in the midterm and top 25% in the final, above mean for each homework, got A-.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is appropriate. Two (simple) homeworks, midterm and final.

reviews.author: Tiere
reviews.comment_content: Though I do not enroll in a proper UG network class, I think the content is almost the same as a UG course, without more advanced stuffs. So if you have taken a UG network course, this class can be not so useful, and using this class to easily satisfy credit needs seem not very easy (check the grading section). But if you have not learned network at all, this course can be some simple start.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is fine. I understand most things, though I still need to check the slides and textbook sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fine: most people get passed (B+ or above for PG student), but getting A+ seems extremely difficult. In fact even getting A requires some effort. I get A- personally with a very low quiz score.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is really light: 3 assignments with the last one not count towards final grades, 2 quizzes and 1 final exam. I finish each assignment in roughly 2-3 hours.

reviews.author: ianylin
reviews.comment_content: I have taken this course in UG, I think this course is the same as what I took. This course will help the learners to understand the basic concepts of computer networks and network protocol.
reviews.comment_teaching:
the professor is nice and humorous;
there's more handwriting which is hard to recognize.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading includes 4 assignments and the mid/final exam.
The professor declares if you are not good at English, he won't take it into consideration, as long as he knows if you are in the scope of the right answer.

reviews.author: michaelK
reviews.title: Overall Great
reviews.comment_content: The content is about TCP/IP model. If you have studied it as a UG, then this course barely cover new stuff for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: The delivery is smooth and intriguing. The professor clarified some concepts not clear to me when I was a UG.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fare and no need to appeal. It has specific standards to balance the grading of assignments and exams. The midterm and final-term are pretty similar each year.
reviews.comment_workload: Balanced workload. You will have 3 or 4 assignments (I don't remember the exact number). The questions could be answered according to the lectures.

reviews.author: Wensheng TANG
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content: Maybe you have taken Computer Networks course during the undergraduate period, this PG course helps you get deeper understanding of Computer Network structure, by a top-down approaches.
reviews.comment_teaching: BB is very good at teaching and like to offer latest information about some protocol stack and encourage you to read RFC documents yourselves. If you like to work on protocols, you shouldn't miss one lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: If you works hard enough on homework and textbook exercises, you should easily get fair enough grade even if you fail on either midterm or final.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 assignments & midterm. No programming assignments. No presentations or any essays.

reviews.author: Croc
reviews.comment_content: I think the major content is the same as what I studied in ug stage. When I was taking the course, I tended not to take the lecture but look at the slides.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is just ok. BB will follow the textbook. His illustration is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very good. As long as you finish the homework and got some points in exam, you can get B+.
For exam, a suggesting is to finish all the problem sets in the Computer Network: Top down approach. It will be enough for the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Just need to spend time on the 4 homeworks.

reviews.author: Stonycat
reviews.title: Awesome Course
reviews.comment_content: The content is about TCP/IP model. If you have studied it as a UG, then this course barely cover new stuff for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: The delivery is smooth and intriguing. The professor clarified some concepts not clear to me when I was a UG.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fare and no need to appeal. It has specific standards to balance the grading of assignments and exams. The midterm and final-term are pretty similar each year.
reviews.comment_workload: Balanced workload. You will have 3 or 4 assignments (I don't remember the exact number). The questions could be answered according to the lectures.

reviews.author: lzhangbv
reviews.comment_content: It includes the basic knowledge of computer network, according to the textbook of Computer Network: A Top-Down Approach (chapters 1-6).
reviews.comment_teaching: Great Teaching. The teacher is good at explaining things in detail.
reviews.comment_grading: Easy to get high grade. As it is the PG's course, I think it may be easier to get high grade than UG's computer network course. And the two exams (mid-term and final-term) are not hard since you can go through the past paper and be familiar with these questions.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not high. You would have 3 assignments. And the labs are very easy by using Wireshark. Also open book and open note exams.

reviews.author: Benben Ng
reviews.comment_content: Standard networking stuff, nothing too exciting. May be too easy if you have some previous experience working with network.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great teaching. It is fun in BB's lecture. He is presenting the material with animated power points which allows better understanding. Also very kind to answer questions, in great detail, either during lecture or email.
reviews.comment_grading: Easy A range. As it is a PG course it is graded pretty nice. As the exam ask for more thinking question and less memorizing questions, you need to understand the material.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. There are 3 assignments asking questions about the content and some wireshark tasks. Easy enough to finish within an hour. Also open book and open note exam.
